highlights.para: This chapter covers issues and questions you might have concerning Ubuntu installation. We will also cover installing Ubuntu inside a virtual machine and installing non-free software.

sect2.title: Will Ubuntu support my hardware?
sect2.para: Ubuntu mainly provides the software packages and uses Debian's package management system. The hardware is controlled by the Linux kernel. So you may want to check your favorite web search engine for the keywords 'linux' and 'hardware'. There are already a few well-known resources where you can check if your hardware is supported.

sect2.title: I have an applicationle system with only one mouse button. How can I perform actions which require right-clicking or middle-clicking?
sect2.para: The F11 and F12 keys can be used to simulate these actions.

sect2.title: What is the recommended RAM and how much hard drive space does Ubuntu need?
sect2.para: To install Ubuntu you should have at least 32MB of RAM.
You should have space on your hard disk to create a new disk partition of at least 1.8 GB for a standard Ubuntu desktop system, or at least 350 MB for a minimal custom installation.

sect2.title: Does Ubuntu work in Microsoft Virtual PC 2004?
sect2.para: Yes, with a quick manual hack. Ubuntu currently auto-configures XFree86? during the installation process, asking the user only what resolutions they'd like to enable. The default color depth is automatically set to 24-bpp, and Microsoft Virtual PC 2004 does not support 24-bpp color depth. In practice, this results in garbled graphics output when the X Server starts and the login screen is displayed. To fix this problem, you may manually change the default color depth setting in the XFree86? config file.
These directions assume that you have installed Ubuntu as your guest operating system normally, have rebooted, and have seen the garbled graphics output.

itemizedlist.listitem: In Microsoft Virtual PC, select Action->Reset to reboot the virtual machine.
Watch for the GNU GRUB prompt (don't blink or you'll miss it) and hit ESC when you see it.
Select the option in GRUB for recovery mode, and wait for Ubuntu to boot into the shell. Then type:
su root (you may have to type your password at this point, I'm not sure)
Now, scroll down in emacs to Section "Screen" and find the entry named "DefaultDepth?". Change the setting you find there from 24 to 16.
Hit F10, f, s to save your changes
Hit F10, f, e to exit emacs
Reboot the virtual machine again as described in step 1.

sect2.para: That's it - the virtual machine should now boot successfully into the beautiful minimalist Ubuntu login screen.

sect2.title: How do I get VMware to work after reboots?
sect2.para: Using VMware under Ubuntu causes some problems because of Ubuntu's use of udev. Until the VMware developers have created a patch for this, here is a quick way to hack in 'support' for udev :)

listitem.para: First clear VMware's "Not Configured"-flag so that the next time, when you try to start VMware, you won't have to reconfigure VMware first. If it exists:

Next we need to edit /etc/init.d/vmware. Find the following text (around line 800):
case "$1" in start) And insert the following text right under those two lines: for a in `seq 0 9`; do mknod /dev/vmnet$a c 119 $a > /dev/null 2>&1 done mknod /dev/vmmon c 10 165 > /dev/null 2>&1
Now run /etc/init.d/vmware start and the program should work again.

sect2.title: Where are Flash / Java / mp3 support? Is there a Free and working DVD player or video player?
sect2.para: There are a number of commonly used formats and tools that we are unable to support because they have restrictive distribution rights, require special licenses, or are patent encumbered. We may be able to provide support for some of these in restricted, but in general, we would prefer to support Free software and Free formats.

If you add the debian-marillat repository to your Ubuntu sources.list (use testing/main), you can use Synaptic or apt-get to install MPlayer, lame, and other tools to deal with non-free formats like DVD and MP3.

A relatively clean way of getting Totem to work with all the proprietary file formats is to install totem-xine rather than totem-gstreamer. Then you can download the win32 codecs from elsewhere and install them in ~/.gnome2/totem-addons/ and everything works fine. Of course, this isn't as cool and integrated as using GStreamer for handling all the media, but it works well.
If you wish to use the Java SDK/RE, see Java on Debian for an installation guide (it's also valid for Ubuntu).

As an alternative to the above mentioned Java on Debian tutorial, you may wish to install some pre-packaged packages. The website http://z42.de/debian/ lists an apt source that lets you install for example Sun Java2 v1.5 with a single command:apt-get install sun-j2sdk1.5 sun-j2sdk1.5debian

sect2.title: Which packages are available in Ubuntu?
sect2.para: Ubuntu contains essentially all of the packages available in the Debian repositories, as well as many packages from third-party sources. Many packages are customised to integrate smoothly with the Ubuntu system, to fix bugs, and to provide newer versions of software. In the future, a website will be provided which lists all of the available software.

sect2.title: Do you provide packages compiled with processor-specific optimisations? Where can I find them?

itemizedlist.listitem: Optimised kernels can be obtained by installing the "linux-686", "linux-k7", etc. packages. Search for "linux" with Synaptic, aptitude or apt-cache.
An optimised C library is installed by default, in the libc6-i686 packages.
Optimised cryptography routines for i586- and i686-class systems are included with the OpenSSL library and used automatically

All Ubuntu packages are compiled using the i486 instruction set, with instruction choices based on the Pentium 4 processor. This combination provides benefits for modern processors without sacrificing compatibility with older and embedded devices.

sect2.para: A comprehensive experiment to evaluate the effectiveness of more aggressive processor optimisations for all Ubuntu packages is planned after the Warty release.

sect2.title: I need newer versions of some Ubuntu packages, such as I am accustomed to receiving in Debian unstable. Where can I find them?
sect2.para: Soon after the Warty release, updated packages will be available in our development branch on an ongoing basis, similar to the pace of Debian unstable.

sect2.title: What kind of software does the multiverse repository contain?
sect2.para: Software in the "multiverse" component has not been determined to be Free Software.

Please make certain that you verify your rights to use this software and comply with the licensing terms of the copyright holder. This software receives no support and usually cannot be fixed or updated. Use it at your own risk.

sect2.title: Can I use both Ubuntu and Debian packages together, in the same sources.list?
sect2.para: In general, it's not a very good idea. While Debian and Ubuntu are compatible to a large degree, and share many of the same source packages, the binary packages are not identical due to having been built independently. This causes unexpected effects in the package management system.
However, in general, this is not an issue, for one simple reason: essentially all of the software in Debian is also available in Ubuntu repositories, so there is no reason to mix the two.

sect2.title: Is it possible to upgrade from Debian Sarge to Ubuntu Warty Warthog simply by adding the "deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu warty main restricted universe" lines to /etc/apt/sources.list?
sect2.para: This is not supported, though a few brave souls have done it and reported mixed results. Sarge and Warty froze at similar times, so some of the code in Warty is newer than code in Sarge, and vice-versa. For example, Warty includes Gnome 2.8, while Sarge is Gnome 2.6. Just trying to switch sources in sources.list will have interesting and undefined results. Please feel free, if you are also feeling brave, to try it and update this answer or the wiki with your results.

sect2.title: Can I upgrade directly from Debian Woody to Ubuntu?
sect2.para: Yes, you can upgrade directly from Debian Woody to Ubuntu 4.10 (Warty Warthog). Notes and caveats about the upgrade process can be found here.

sect2.title: Do you include XFree86 or X.org?
sect2.para: Warty Warthog includes XFree86 4.3.99 packages with much improved hardware support. The next Ubuntu release, codenamed Hoary Hedgehog will use the X.org server instead.

sect2.title: Does Ubuntu come with a firewall installed?
sect2.para: Since Ubuntu doesn't run any daemons that listen to the outside world by default (the postfix install only listens on localhost) there's no need for a default firewall.
The rationale is that if a user's got a need for installing a world-facing daemon, they'll be aware that they should configure a firewall/ACL for it too.

sect2.title: Where is gpdf?
sect2.para: GNOME 2.8's version of gpdf is available in universe. We decided to ship xpdf for WartyWarthog instead, as gpdf doesn't support text searching and Type3 fonts. It should do, by the time we release HoaryHedgehog with GNOME 2.10.

sect2.title: Does Warty Warthog / Ubuntu include complete multimedia support?
sect2.para: We're still working out some of the difficult legal / policy issues involved with multimedia support. Warty Warthog includes some basic multimedia support, but limited by what we can safely and freely do. Specific information is available for some multimedia issues in the RestrictedFormats wiki page.

sect2.title: How do I get Firefox to open a new tab when I click a link?
sect2.para: Edit the file /etc/mozilla-firefox/mozilla-firefoxrc and change the line that reads FIREFOX_OPEN_IN="window" to be FIREFOX_OPEN_IN="tab". There is a comment about this on the line above.

sect2.title: Does Ubuntu include Mono and applications based on Mono?
sect2.para: Mono is not included in our Warty Warthog release, but may be included in future releases.

sect2.title: Where are the icons on the desktop? I want my Trashcan, Computer and Home icons on the desktop!
sect2.para: In Warty Warthog, we decided to try out a new way of getting to all the important locations on your computer and across the network, which complements the spatial design behind Nautilus very nicely.

Icons on the desktop are almost always obscured by windows when you're getting work done, and it's often a pain to move them out of the way or switch to a different workspace to get at them. So, we've turned all of the special desktop icons off, and provided access to them in the Computer menu. No more window tidying when you just want to open your file manager!

We've included trashapplicationlet, which provides a working trash icon on your panel, so it's always accessible. In the future, we'd like to make it so that you can delete anything - not just files - by dragging to the trash.

If you want to turn some of the special desktop icons back on, run applications > System Tools > Configuration Editor, navigate to /applications/nautilus/general, and choose the icons you want to applicationear.

sect2.title: What background images are available for widescreen laptops and displays?
sect2.para: The Ubuntu Default Desktop and Ubuntu Monthly Calendar images are also available in a 16:9 aspect ratio for those with widescreen laptops and displays.

sect2.title: When I browse my network using the "Windows Network" method I can see all of the machines, but only connect to XP workstations. When I try to connect to Windows 2003 Servers, I get a permissions error. Now, when I try "Connect to Server" method, I fill out the details and enter my password when asked, it responds by asking for the password again. I have also added a computer account to Windows server for my Unbuntu machine then repeated these steps with the same results.
sect2.para: It seems entering 'servername' in the server field and 'sharename' in the share field is not sufficient. Try putting 'servername/sharename' in the server field and leaving the share field blank. We understand this is very counter-intuitive, but it works, we're working to improve this user interface.

sect2.title: My wireless network uses WEP encryption for better security. How can I set up Ubuntu to connect to it?
sect2.para: Ubuntu's Network Settings dialog has support for wireless network cards. Network configuration is in 'Computer -> System Configuration -> Networking'

sect2.title: What's the root password after I install? How do I use the root account?
sect2.para: The root account is disabled when you first install Ubuntu. The first user created during the installation has administrative rights on the system, and can run programs as root with sudo, using only their normal user password. For example: sudo apt-get update.

All uses of sudo will require the user's password.Note that the root account does not have a password at all after the initial install. You can set the root password by typing sudo passwd root.If you need a shell with root privileges, run sudo -s. The benefits of this are mentioned in the wiki here.

Please keep in mind that booting into recovery mode only works if you have a root password set. Otherwise the only way to access your system in case of problems is to use a Live CD and mount your filesystem.

sect2.title: The default installation is for a graphical desktop environment, but I'd like to install a server or other minimal system. How can I do this?
sect2.para: Type "custom" at the initial CD-ROM boot prompt. This will install only the base packages, after which you can install only what you need, using 'aptitude' or 'apt-get'.

sect2.title: How can I boot Ubuntu with different options using grub?
sect2.para: You can have grub boot the kernel using different options for just the one boot by changing the boot command line using grub's interactive mode:

itemizedlist.listitem: When you see the GRUB Loading message, press ESC to get to the grub menu. Here, you will see several lines with kernel descriptions in them: select the one that does not say '''recovery''' using the arrow keys.

Press e to edit the commands associated with that kernel. This will bring up another screen with various options, the one you are looking for has kernel in it. Using the arrow keys, select the line with kernel in it and press e to edit the line.
This will take you to a screen with the contents of the line in it, just add your new command at the end, then press enter.

You will be returned to the previous menu and you should be able to see your altered boot options added to the line you edited (unless the boor command line is too long). Press b to boot using the edited boot command.

sect2.para: Ubuntu will now load with your new option enabled.

sect2.title: How do I permanently change the options grub uses to boot Ubuntu?
sect2.para: Ok, so you have used the above technique and found that you need to permanently make a change to the grub parameters, here is what you need to do.

itemizedlist.listitem: Edit /boot/grub/menu.lst (e.g., sudo gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst)
Find the line which looks like: kopt root=/dev/hda1 ro
Add your parameters to the end of the line
Save your changesRun sudo update-grub
Run sudo update-grub
Reboot

sect2.title: How do I change the Login Screen image?

itemizedlist.listitem: Computer -> System Configuration -> Login Screen Setup
Enter your password if prompted
Choose the Graphical greeter tab
Select an alternate theme

sect2.title: How do I change the Splash Screen image?

itemizedlist.listitem: applications -> System Tools -> Configuration Editor
Choose /applications/gnome-session/options from the tree on the left
Change the splash_image key to (e.g.) splash/ubuntu-logo-508x340.png
